He must treat his teeth as soon as possible because it is terrible sick. Khurshed is asking for a loan of 5000 Somoni to treat his teeth. He awaits your mercy.

loans.use: To treat his teeth

loans.name: Sokrorn

texts.en:
K. Sokrorn is a mother of three in Phnom Penh, who is currently selling food in front of the local factories. She is making approximately $7.50 a day from selling food. After seeing her friend successfully open a store, K. Sokrorn decided that she would like to open a grocery store. Therefore, she is applying for her first loan from CREDIT MFI in order to acquire the inventory for her store. She is requesting $500 to purchase fruits, vegetables, and other products for the store.

 

K. Sokrorn and her husband, who is a moto taxi driver, are expecting this new grocery store to help them improve the lives of their children. They would like to use the additional income they will receive from the business to build a new home and purchase cows.

loans.use: Running Capital for a grocery shop

loans.name: Israfil

texts.en:
Israfil runs this business for 10 years. He is 40, married, has a child, lives in Fizuli region Mahmudlu village.
He needs a loan of $1200 to buy milch cow, fodder and medicinal preparations.

loans.use: To buy a milch cow

loans.name: Rigoberto

texts.en:
Rigoberto is a hard working and responsible man. He is 38 and has a daughter who is in high school. He did not have a steady job, so it was difficult for him to make ends meet and raise his daughter. He then had the opportunity to work at an auto repair shop and learned the trade. After a staff cut, he lost his job and had to start his own business fixing cars at his home or going to the clients.

Now Rigoberto needs a $475 loan to buy tools and a hydraulic jack. He needs these tools to provide better service for his clients and be more efficient at his job. He will repay the loan within 4 to 8 months. You can help Rigoberto improve his life and work; he'll be sincerely grateful.

Translated from Spanish by Isabel Tan, a Kiva volunteer.

Rigoberto es muy trabajador y responsable, tiene 38 años y una hija que estudia la secundaria. Él no tenía un trabajo fijo por lo que se le dificultaba solventar todos sus gastos y el mantenimiento de su hija, posteriormente se le presentó la oportunidad de laborar en un taller mecánico, donde aprendió el oficio, pero después del recorte de personal en el taller quedó desempleado y tuvo la necesidad de emprender su propio negocio, ahora realiza los trabajos de reparación en su domicilio o en el de sus clientes.

En estos momentos Rigoberto requiere de un préstamo por la cantidad de $475 dólares que empleará en la compra de herramienta y un gato hidráulico, que necesita para ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes y ser más eficiente en su trabajo, él ofrece devolver el préstamo en un lapso de 4 a 8 meses. Tú puedes contribuir a mejorar las condiciones de vida y de trabajo de Rigoberto, él agradece sinceramente tu ayuda.

loans.use: Compra de herramienta

loans.name: Petrona

texts.es:
Petrona is 36 years old. She has four children. She separated from her husband due to his alcohol and physical abuse. She makes corn "tostadas" and sells them in San Cristobal de las Casas, which is about an hour away from where she lives. Petrona is part of a solidarity group called Azalia3 integrated by: Irma Sanchez Santiago, who also makes corn "tostadas", and Cristina Hernandez Bautista, who owns a store at home. Petrona and Irma would use the loan to purchase corn and firewood. Cristina would use it to enlarge her store. They are very hard working women who not only want their business to grow, but also want to better their economic condition.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

PETRONA TIENE 36 AÑOS, CUATRO HIJOS, SEPARADA DE SU ESPOSO POR CAUSA DEL ALCOHOL Y EL MAL TRATO. ELLA SE DEDICA A ELABORAR TOSTADAS DE MAIZ Y LO VENDE EN LA CIUDAD DE SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS UBICADO A UNA HORA DE DONDE VIVE. PETRONA FORMA PARTE DE UN GRUPO SOLIDARIO LLAMADO AZALIA 3 QUIENES LO INTEGRAN: IRMA SANCHEZ SANTIAGO QUE ELABORA TOSTADAS DE MAIZ Y CRISTINA HERNANDEZ BAUTISTA TIENE UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES EN SU CASA. CON EL PRESTAMO PETRONA E IRMA COMPRARAN LEÑA Y MAIZ, CRISTINA COMPRARA LO NECESARIO PARA AMPLIAR SU TIENDA DE ABARROTES. ELLAS SON MUJERES TRABAJADORAS QUE NO SOLAMENTE QUIEREN QUE SU NEGOCIO CREZCA SINO TAMBIEN MEJORAR SU CONDICION ECONOMICA.

loans.use: Purchase corn and firewood to produce artisan food

loans.name: Ung

texts.en:
Mrs. Ung S. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She runs a shop at her home selling rice and food to the people in her community, earning around $5 each day. Her husband, meanwhile, is a driver making $5 each day, One of her children is a mechanic earning $6 a day and the rest are students. 
This loan will be used to help her son buy more mechanical tools to operate his business.

loans.use: To purchase mechanical tools to operate a business.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine L. is a Ugandan by nationality, an Acholi by tribe, and is 38 years of age. She is a married woman with four children. L. and her family left Gulu because of the war that was in the north. It was so terrible to the extent that it took so many people's lives. In 1998, L. and her family fled to Kampala and settled on the land (the Acholi Quarters) which was offered to them by the King of Buganda to settle on since he had sympathy for the people of northern Uganda.

When Christine settled in the camp, she began to work in the stone quarry to earn some income. From the stone quarry, she was earning 1000 /= (about 60 cents; the symbol /= here stands for Uganda shillings) per day. As time went on, she worked even harder and was able to earn 2000 Uganda shillings (about US$ 1.20) per day. This is how much she is still earning now, which makes her earn 60,000 shillings (about US$ 35) per month.

In 2005, Christine joined Life in Africa Foundation where she learned how to make paper beads and started to earn 60,000 to 100,000 shillings most months. L. used her earnings to start a small business that she runs by herself where she sells things like tomatoes, cabbages, green vegetables, and onions. She does well but with a large family she needs to increase her income to provide for their needs.

Christine's plan is to add capital to expand her business. Demand is high but she needs to add stock to meet this demand. She also wants to add sim sim (sesame seeds, a Ugandan staple food) and charcoal to her inventory which will further increase her profits. To do this she is seeking a loan in the amount of 250,000 Uganda shillings (US$ 150). She will earn a good profit on this investment, around 110,000 to 130,000/= each month and feels sure she will be able to repay this loan in 4 months.

Below is how Christine is going to use the 250,000 shillings: -

Buying cabbages…………………..40,000/=

Onions……………………..10,000/=

Tomatoes…………………..30,000/=

Green vegetables…………………30,000/=

Transport for the month……30,000/=

Sim-sim for………………...110,000/=

Total…………………………….250,000/= (US$ 150)

loans.use: expanding her little grocery store

loans.name: Anzerani

texts.en:
Anzerani is a small entrepreneur who owns a small restaurant and small shop selling clothes. She is married to Hamisi Rashid who is also working with her in the business. She has five children. She is very successful in the business and helping her family. After two wonderful loan repayments, she is asking for a loan to buy catering equipments, chairs and tables. She is proposing to repay the loan in 12 months. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and they are thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

loans.use: Buying catering equipment, chairs and tables

loans.name: Fakhraddin

texts.en: Fakhraddin has been in this business for 3 years. He buys beer from the Guba region and transports to the Khachmaz region in Azerbaijan for sale. He is married and has 3 children. Fakhraddin lives in the Khachmaz region of Azerbaijan, with his family. He needs a loan of $725 to buy beer to increase his inventory.

loans.use: to buy beer

loans.name: Juana Yolanda

texts.es:
Juana is 39 years of age, married and has two children; a 16 year old daughter who is in her first year of college and a 14 year old boy who is in middle school. Her husband is a security guard and Juana works at a sports club. This family has limited financial resources and their salaries do not complete the cost of maintaining their home. That is why Juana decided to sell various products based on customer orders, by either credit or cash sales. Juana needs the loan to purchase uniforms and school supplies being that she has many orders to fill as classes are about to begin in many schools. This is how Juana has fought to be able to provide for her two children with the support of her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Wendy Wise

Doña Juana tiene 39 años de edad, casada, tiene 2 hijos una mujer de 16 años que cursa I año de la universidad y un varon de 14 años que cursa la educación secundaria. Su esposo es guarda de seguridad y Doña Juana trabaja de conserje en un lub deportivo. Esta familia es de muy bajo recursos económicos, y los salarios no completan los gastos del hogar. Es por eso que Juana decidío vender productos varios por encargo, ya se al crédito o al contado. Doña Juana necesita el préstamo para comprar uniformes y utiles escolares ya que tiene muchos pedidos porque las clases en los colegios están por iniciar. Es así como Doña Juana ha luchado por sacar adelante a sus 2 hijos con el apoyo de su esposo. .

loans.use: Purchase uniforms and school supplies.  Comprar Uniformes y Utiles Escolares

loans.name: Vusal

texts.en: Vusal M. is a 24-year-old internally displaced person from Aghdam, Azerbaijan. His uncle passed down his knowledge of ceramic tile works. There’s demand for Vusal's work in the district where he lives. The problem is that he is using his uncle’s tools, which saw their good days years ago.  He is sure that the new tools he will buy with Kiva loan support will increase his productivity so he can make more money to support his family.  Vusal got married a year ago.

loans.use: Purchase of new tools to increase the speed of work and productivity

loans.name: Sayaad Habib

texts.en: Sayaad Habib lives in district 13 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a single young man who lives with his own family. He is a butcher and he has the responsibility for his family. His father fell ill and died, so he is the one to support his family. He needs to expand his business so he has requested an individual loan to complete his stock and increase his business. He is happy with all parts of his family.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Zulma Selena

texts.es:
Zulma Selene Altamirano León is 20 years old and completed her studies up to middle school. She is considering pursuing a specialized career, but she is still saving up to make this happen. She is a single woman without children, and lives in the El Porvenir district in the Trujillo province in La Libertad, Perú.

Since she finished her middle school studies, she started a business selling processed meats such as bologna, hot dogs, canned ham, cheese and other products of that variety, and distributed them among the different footwear manufacturing workshops. She also creates shoeboxes, purchasing cardboard and cutting it according to the requests she receives. She then sends them to print and finally, she builds them. She receives orders from the owners of these footwear workshops.

She is a member of the communal bank “Bendición de Dios” (Grace from God). From this bank, she received her first loan of S/. 300.00, which she used to purchase several cases of bologna and ham and another part to purchase a display case where she could exhibit some candies outside her home to sell to neighbors.

With the loan of S/. 900.00, which she will repay in 4 months, she will purchase on a weekly basis: a package of hot dogs, two cases of bologna, cheese and prime materials to create the boxes such as cardboard, staples, raffia, etc.

Her greatest wish is to attend school and complete her nursing degree successfully.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señorita Zulma Selene Altamirano León tiene 20 años de edad, estudio secundaria completa, esta pensando en seguir estudiando una carrera tecnica pero todavía esta ahorrando para realizarlo. Es una joven soltera y sin hijos. Vive en el distrito de El Porvenir en la provincia de Trujillo en el departamento La Libertad – Perú.

Desde que termino de estudiar en el colegio emprendió un negocio, se dedica a la venta de embutidos tales como mortadela, hod dog, jamonada, quesos y otros productos de ese origen, reparte por los diferentes talleres de fabricación de calzados. Además se dedica a elaborar cajas para calzados, compra el cartón y lo corta de acuerdo a como se requiera, luego las manda estampar y finalmente las arma, tiene pedidos de los dueños de los talleres de calzado.

Ella es socia del Banco Comunal “Bendición de Dios” en este banco recibió su primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 con este dinero compro algunos conos de mortadela y jamonada y con otra parte del dinero compro una vitrina para exhibir algunas golosinas afuera de su domicilio para vender a los vecinos.

Con el préstamo de S/. 900.00 el cual cancelara en cuatro meses comprará: semanalmente un paquete de hod dog, dos conos de mortadela, queso y material para elaborar las cajas tales como: cartón, grapas, rafia, etc.

Su mayor sueño es estudiar y terminar con éxito la carrera profesional de enfermería.

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise for her store (a package of hot dogs, two cases of bologna, cheese and prime materials to create shoeboxes such as cardboard, staples, raffia, etc.).

loans.name: Matluba

texts.ru:
Matluba Ergashevna M. lives in the city of Tursun-Zoda. She is 21 years old and has a high school degree. Matluba has a small bakery at the local market of Tursun-Zoda where she bakes rolls and filled savory pastries (pirozhki). Her parents are old and she is their sole supporter. Currently the prices for flour have been rising steadily and Matluba decided to purchase a large batch of flour from the wholesalers to keep the price of her baked goods low. To purchase a large batch of flour Matluba needs money and that is why she wants to take out this loan. She is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Махмудова Матлуба Эргашевна жительница города Турсунзаде. Возраст 21 год, образование среднее. Матлуба имеет небольшой цех на рынке города Турсунзаде. Где производит пирожки и булочки. У Матлубы престарелые родители и ей приходится самой содержать семью. Сейчас идет рост цен на муку и она решила закупить у оптовых поставщиков муку.Для чего ей нужны деньги. Поэтому она решила взять кредит .Планирует погасить кредит в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of flour

loans.name: Esther M.

texts.en:
Hello from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 54 year-old Esther M..  She is a widow and has three children ages 19,24 and 30. She also has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans.  In 2006, Esther  has established a grocery business. She opens her business seven days a week from  nine to twelve hours a day. She is assisted by her  children. Esther  requires a loan in order to buy more soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.  

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; a very cheap marketing tool! All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks.

loans.name: Sophim

texts.en: Mrs. Sophim O. is a pot-maker in Andoung Russey Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Nget Phai, sells firewood. They have two children who are too young to work or attend school. Since Mrs. Sophim O.’s business is doing well, she would like to expand it by selling pots from door-to-door. Thus, Mrs. Sophim O.  has decided to request a loan to buy a cart so she can transport her products to sell. Previously, Mrs. Sophim O. obtained a loan from AMK to buy cows and she has fully paid off the loan. Her husband is shown in the picture on the right.

loans.use: To buy a cart so that she can transport her pots to sell door-to-door.

loans.name: Jhenny Edith

texts.es:
Mrs. Jenny belongs to the communal Bank “El Arenal,” located in Jr. Cesar Calvo de Araujo # 507, district of Calleria in the department of Ucayali. She is 29 years old and has a son and her husband is a driver. With her first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 soles (US $100), Jenny began a business selling clothes and cosmetics.

For the moment she keeps all of the clothing in her house and distributes it from house to house, although her dream is to have a place of her own.

With this loan of 1,500 soles (US $525), which will be repaid in 6 months, she will purchase blouses, pants, Snake brand clothing, lotions, perfumes and others. Jenny is a woman who always likes to work and be independent, and for this reason she likes her business because she can converse with customers and make many friends. This makes her feel more accomplished and happy to belong to the Bank of Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Jenny pertenece al Banco Comunal El Arenal, ubicado en el Jr. Cesar Calvo de Araujo # 507, Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 29 años y tiene un hijo y su esposo es chofer de carro, Jenny con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 implemento su negocio en venta de ropa y cosméticos. Por el momento toda la mercadería lo tiene en su casa que después lo distribuye de casa en casa, aunque su anhelo es contar con un local propio. Con este préstamo de S/ 1,500 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, ella invertirá comprando blusas, pantalones, Snake, cremas, perfumes y otros. Jenny, es una mujer a la que siempre le gusto trabajar y sentirse independiente por eso le gusta su negocio porque puede conversar con sus clientes y hacer muchos amigos, eso la hace sentirse mas realizada y esta feliz de pertenecer al Banco de Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing and cosmetics

loans.name: Marvin Antonio

texts.es:
El caballero Marvin C. se dedica con mucho esfuerzo a la actividad de agricultura atendiéndola en el municipio de San Rafael del Sur y sembrando maíz, sorgo y frijol con el propósito de llevar el sustento a su hogar de habitación compuesto por su cónyuge y su pequeño hijo.

Hoy en día el señor Marvin ha acudido a Ceprodel con el objetivo de obtener un crédito para invertir en la siembra y de igual forma brindar asistencia técnica a los cultivos. Por este motivo es que espera muy confiadamente que su crédito será otorgado y una vez que tenga el dinero invertirá en su actividad de agricultura.
texts.en:
Mr. Marvin Chavarria had dedicated much effort to the business of agriculture in the Southern San Rafael municipality. He plants corn, sorghum (a type of grain) and beans to provide for his wife and little child.

Today, Marvin comes to Ceprodel with the aim of obtaining a loan to invest in planting and cultivating technical assistance. He is very confident that he will be awarded this loan and assures you that the money will be invested for agricultural activities.

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Agricultural cultivation assistance.

loans.name: Mkombozi A Group

texts.en:
Noadia, 31 years old and divorced with three children aged 2, 9, and 12, as well as three additional dependents, has been selling drinks in Dodoma, Tanzania since 2006. She works 12 hours everyday and nets a profit of approximately $65 each month.

Noadia is requesting her first loan in order to expand this young business and buy a greater quantity of water, soda, and beer to sell at her shop. As her sales increase and her profit grows, she hopes to put more money towards food for her family.

Noadia will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Rose and Amina.

loans.use: To buy more water, soda, and beer to sell.

loans.name: Delfina

texts.en:
Delfina is a member of the Paloma (“Dove”) Village Bank. She is 61 years old and married with four adult children. Most of her children are finishing their studies, so she still supports them financially. Delfina owns a dry goods store, which she has run since 1975. She also runs a bar in the same space. 

Delfina is requesting a loan of 2,000 soles to buy dry goods (rice, flour sugar, etc.) and boxes of beer. She used to buy beer on a daily basis and have it delivered to the store, but she has since started buying larger orders twice per week. She buys 20 boxes at a time for 33.80 soles per box, and she earns 6.80 soles for each box she sells. In the future, Delfina is thinking about installing a call center in her store, but she isn’t sure she has enough money to do so right now. 

Delfina is a long-time client of FINCA. She says she has been working with the institution for almost as long as it has existed (about 15 years).

loans.use: Buy dry goods and beer

loans.name: Henry Rosalio

texts.es: Don Henry está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 8vo crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (Construcción de los servicios Higienicos), trabaja como Análista de crédito en FINCA NICARAGUA,     tiene 3 hijos, el mayor de 13 años estudia 2do año de educación secundaria, la otra hija de 11 años estudia 6to grado de Educación primaria y el niño menor de 3 añitos, su esposa trabaja en el mercado munipal de Nueva Guinea, ambos comparte los gastos del hogar; don Henry es un hombre profesional responsable, honesto, trabajador, vive en la zona # 6 de Nueva Guinea donde la población cada dia crece mas, actualmente  esta estudiando un  postgrado   en la Univesidad  URACCAN Recinto Nueva Guinea,    su sueño es seguir  estudiando, tener salud, estabilidad laboral y en el futuro tener una casa bonita con todas las condiciones para su familia.
texts.en:
Henry would like to refinance his eighth loan to invest in constructing a bathroom in his home. He is a credit analyst at FINCA NICARAGUA and has three children. His oldest is 13 and in the second year of secondary school, his 11-year-old daughter is in sixth grade, and his youngest is 3 years old. His wife works in his neighborhood's market and they both share responsibility for household expenses.

Henry is a responsible, honest, hard-working professional. He lives in Zone 6 of the Nueva Guinea neighborhood, where the population grows by the day. He is currently doing postgraduate work at the Nueva Guinea campus of URACCAN University. He dreams of continuing his studies and of having good health, employment security, and a beautiful, well-appointed home for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To construct a bathroom

loans.name: Juana Dolores

texts.en:
Juana is a member of the Desarrollo (“Development”) Village Bank.  Juana is 38 years old and lives with her partner and their two children. Juana lives in the Huayllapampa community, located about 30 minutes outside of the city of Ayacucho. Juana has a small store in her house, where she sells dry goods and vegetables. In prickly pear season, Juana also buys prickly pears to send to Lima to sell.  Juana needs a loan of 2000 soles, which she will use to buy rice, sugar, pills and dried beans.  Juana dreams of selling wholesale and of providing her children with a good education. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Juana es socia del Banco Comunal Desarrollo. 
Juana es conviviente, tiene 38 años y 2 hijos, Juana vive en la comunidad de Huayllapampa que se ubica a 30 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, Juana tiene una bodega en su casa en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además Juana en época de producción de tuna compra y lo envía a la ciudad de Lima. 
Juana necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar, pastillas, menestras. 
Juana sueña con tener una tienda mayorista, brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, pills and dried beans

loans.name: Lyutfiya

texts.en:
Lyutfiya S. is 37 years old. She is married and the loving mother of 4 children. All her children are in school. Lyutfiya's husband is a builder and his income is not very high; that is why she decided to start her own business so that she could help him cover their living expenses. She is selling teenagers' clothing in the local market of Dushanbe city. She is trying to have wide range of goods so as to be able to meet the requirements of her customers and to satisfy the needs of the customers with different levels of income.

Today Lyutfiya is requesting 600 USD with the purpose of purchasing additional merchandise to increase the range of her goods. She promises to repay the loan within 6 months. Be an important part of the growth of Lyutfiya’s business!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new underwear for women

loans.name: Ismael

texts.es:
Ismael inició el negocio porqué trabajo como empleado en muchas empresas y nunca pudo lograr una antigüedad para pensionarme por lo que ml fue necesario buscar otro medio de vida para sostenerme. 
Comenzó el negocio En Mayo de 2002 cuando el gobierno le vendió una concesión para Taxi ya que anteriormente en sus tiempos libres trabajaba en un transporte de ruta fija, pero como esta ruta desapareció  el gobierno los apoyó dándonos concesiones de Taxi pero el tuvo que adquirir el Taxi, con el cual le ha ido muy bien y ya esta pensando, incluso quiere  comprar un microbús usado un poquito mas adelante para seguir creciendo. 

A Ismael le ha ido muy bien aunque tiene que trabajar mucho para que salgan los gastos ya que con los aumentos constantes de la gasolina le queda menos margen de ganancia pero aun así el se esfuerza dia con dia para salir adelante, con el anterior crédito pudo reparar un golpe que tenia su taxi en un costado y ahora luce mejor. 


El necesita un prestamo por MXN $3300 que pagara en 8 catorcenas para poder comprar llantas y el servicio de afinación, así como algunas refacciones para poder brindar a sus clientes un servicio cómodo y seguro.
texts.en:
Ismael started the business because he worked as an employee for several companies and was never able to gain enough seniority at any one place to get a pension. He had to find another way to help himself so he started this business in May 2002 after the government sold him a concession to operate a cab. Before that, he used to work on a "transporte de ruta fija" (a bus or vehicle that operates along a set route), but the route was dropped and the government extended the concession to operate a cab. Ismael had to buy the cab, but the business has gone well and now he's even thinking of buying a slightly-used minibus so that he can continue to expand.

The business has served Ismael well but he has to work hard to pay the bills and the constant rise in gas prices has squeezed his earnings. Nevertheless, he works day in and day out to get ahead. He used a previous loan to repair damage to one side of the cab and now it looks better.

He needs a MXN$3,300 loan, to be repaid in 8 14-day installments, to buy tires and servicing, along with some other repairs that will allow him to provide a safer and more comfortable service to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tires and service cab for taxi business.

loans.name: Yom

texts.en: Mrs. Yom S. lives in Tonle village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, she and her husband, Mr. Meb Kang, are sellers. Since this business is going well, they want to sell door-to-door. Thus, Mrs. Yom S. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike to sell her products. She is 43 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is a hard-working man while the others are enrolled in the local school. She and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Mame Coumba

texts.fr: Mame Coumba D., 68 ans, mariée, avec 05 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Bayouf Palal depuis 12 ans. Son activité est la vente d’arachide et de bois de chauffe. Elle veut renforcer son commerce .Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Mame Coumba D., age 68, is married and has five children to support. She has been a member of the village lending group of Bayouf Palal for twelve years. Her work involves selling peanuts and firewood. She wants to bolster her business. The loan she’s requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell peanuts and firewood

loans.name: Sot's Group

texts.en:
This is a small loan for five women who live in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. The group leader, Mrs. Sot N., age 34, is a good mother of three teenage children who are school age. Her husband is a military policeman. Currently, N. earns a living by distilling rice wine as well as raising a few pigs for sale in a pigpen out of her home. N. normally uses the remainder of the wine for the pigs to eat so she can save the cost of pig food. Because the business of breeding pigs is going well and is profitable, N. has requested a loan to purchase more piglets to raise. The other four borrowers are: 
N. is a single woman selling groceries, who needs a loan to increase inventory.
S. is a widowed mother selling cakes in her home and she requests a loan to use as capital for the business.
N. sells cakes for kids in the village and she will use the loan to support her husband's business of growing vegetables.
M. makes Khmer wine and raises pigs for sale and she is applying for a loan to begin selling groceries.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise

loans.name: Nisolat

texts.ru: Нисолат женщина 55 лет, которая продаёт женскую одежду на воскресных больших базарах Худжанда.Товар привозит с Бишкека, сама, ездит на такси один раз в месяц.Нисолат хочет для расширения летнего ассортимента товаров получить очередной кредит.Она ни разу пока не нарушала критерии кредитования и во время погашает свои займы.Нисолат на месте своего бизнеса во время торгового дня.
texts.en:
Nisolat is a 55-year-old woman that sells women's clothing at Khujand's big Sunday bazaars. She brings in the goods herself by taxi once a month from Bishkek. Nisolat would like to take out a loan to expand her range of summer items. She has always complied with the terms of her loans, and made her payments on time. Nisolat is at her place of business during the workday.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of women's clothing

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Laxmi S. is a resident of Tangal. Tangal is located in Lalitpur district. Tangal is one of the busy bazaars in Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses.
Mrs. S. lives in single family with her husband and two sons. Her husband, Mr. Binod S., is engaged in his own small business. Her older son is studying in grade 9 and younger son is in primary school.
Mrs. S. opened her sandal shop in a footpath in Tangal. She opened her shop in a footpath market because she cannot afford to pay high rent in Tangal area. She already has taken a loan from Kiva and has cleared her loan. With her previous loan, she bought different varieties of sandals for boys and girls, selling well and earning well. She is really encouraged to expand her business. Now she is requesting an Rs 30000.00 loan to buy different kinds of sandals for her shop.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of sandals

loans.name: Karla Vanessa

texts.es: La señora Karla Vanesa M. B., tiene la edad de 34 años, habita en el reparto Juan Ramón Padilla, ubicado en el municipio de Ticuantepe, junto a su esposo, él cual le apoya con los gastos del hogar, ellos tienen a su cargo dos hijos una adolescente de doce años, que estudia y un niño de cuatro años de edad. Los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida, para darle un mejor bienestar a los suyos, doña Karla trabaja en almacenes Tropigas, desde hace dos años, su salario no es lo suficiente para cubrir la construcción de sus vivienda, por lo cual necesita el apoyo de nuestra institución, para poder comprar poco a poco materiales para hacer efectiva dicha construcción. Y poder tener una casa digna.
texts.en:
Karla Vanesa M. B. is 34 years old and she lives in the Juan Ramon Padilla area, located in the district of Ticuantepe, with her husband who helps her with the household costs. They look after their 2 kids, their daughter who is twelve years old and studying, and their four year old son. Their plans for the family are to improve their living conidtions. In order to give their kids better well-being Karla has been working in the Tropigas warehouses for two years. Her salary is not enough to cover the building of their house though, and this is why she needs help from our institution; to be able to buy the building materials needed for the construction bit by bit in order to have a decent home.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials for their home/Comprar materiales de construccion para hacer su vivienda

loans.name: Salwa

texts.en:
Salwa is 42 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and five children. She has owned an accessories shop since 2007. The shop coordinates with her husband to to be able to raise the children. 

Today, Salwa is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her accesories shop.

loans.name: Marlene Maclovia

texts.es:
La señora Marlene es socia del Banco Comunal Loma de la Cruz, que se reúne en la oficina de la Fundación ESPOIR en la ciudad de Cuenca cada dos semanas. Ella tiene 48 años y es  madre soltera de 6 hijos, 3 de los cuales viven con ella todavía. La señora es muy alegre y chistosa y tiene la capacidad de hacer reír a todo su banco comunal con sus comentarios. 

Marlene tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de ropa y productos Yanbal. Ella empezó hace más de 20 años cuando trabajaba en una fábrica de tapioca, y se puso a vender estos productos cosmeticos a sus compañeras de trabajo. Ya dejó este trabajo, pero sigue vendiendo a sus antiguas compañeras, y también a sus vecinas, conocidas y familiares. Mas o menos el 50% de sus ventas son de ropa, y la otra mitad es de productos Yanbal como perfumes y cremas. Recibe aproximadamente 4 pedidos por semana, y sus clientes le paguen de forma mensual o quincenal. 

Marlene está pidiendo un préstamo de $880 para poder comprar más ropa y productos Yanbal, ya que sus clientes le pagan después de la entrega de los productos y no de antemano. 

Su meta para el futuro es tener una casa propia. Ya se compró un terreno, y solamente le falta construir la casa.
texts.en:
Señora Marlene is a member of the community bank Loma de la Cruz, which meets in the offices of the foundation ESPOIR, in the city of Cuenca every two weeks. She is 48 years old and is the single mother of 6 children, 3 of whom still live with her. Señora Marlene is very cheerful and funny, and she has the ability to make everyone in the bank laugh with her comments. Marlene has a small business selling clothing and Yanbal products. She began this more than 20 years ago when she was working in a tapioca factory. She began selling these products to her co-workers. She stopped the factory work, but she continued selling to her old co-workers and also to her neighbours, friends, and acquaintances. More or less, 50% of her sales are clothing, and the other half is Yanbul products like perfumes and cremes. She takes about 4 orders a week, and her clients pay her either monthly or quarterly. Marlene is asking for a loan of $880 in order to buy more clothes and Yanbal products, as her clients pay after she delivers the items, and not before. Her goal for the future is to have her own home. She has already purchased some land, and she needs only to construct the house.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and beauty products for Marlene's business

loans.name: Dania Milagros

texts.es:
La socia Dania, es natural de la provincia de Urubamba, ella vive en 1ro de mayo D-8 en el barrio de pintacha, situados a 1 hora con 20 minutos desde la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia es soltera, no tienen hijos ella tiene 25 años de edad y es empleada de una panadería ubicada en el mercado modelo de Urubamba, ella ayuda a la elaboración de panes y también vende los panes que la misma produce, la socia desea el préstamo para uso personal, ella quiere comprar algunos pequeños artefactos para su hogar y cumplir con los pagos mensuales, con lo que le pagan a ella en su trabajo.

Nuestra socia agradece el apoyo brindado y se compromete a cumplir con el pago en el plazo programado.
texts.en:
Dania is a native of Urubamba province and lives in neighborhood of Pintacha, an hour and 20 minutes from the city of Cusco. She is 25 years old, single and has no children. She works at a bakery located in the main market of Urubama, helping bake the breads and also selling the products. Dania is requesting the loan for personal use. She wants to buy a few small items for her home and will fulfill her monthly payments with what she makes for her job. She is thankful for the support and promises to fulfill her payment obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase items for her home

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Yem S. is married and has two school-aged children. She lives with her husband (pictured in front of his house, which is rented to other people) and children in Phnom Penh. To make a living, she sells a type of "hard" alcoholic drink in front of her house, typically earning a gross income of US $3.00 per day. Their primary source of income is her husband’s business. He is a police officer and he rents part of his house to other people, earning collectively an income of US $5.00 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, S. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, S. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $700 to purchase more alcoholic drinks to expand her business. With the remainder of the money, she wants to repair her house. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to raise her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more alcoholic drinks and repair her house

loans.name: Bunthy

texts.en:
Mrs. Bunthy C., 40, and her husband, Mr. Kong Roeun, 49, were married in 1987. They have three children – two sons and one daughter – all of whom are in school. The family live along National Road Number Six about 18 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Bunthy has been selling desserts for ten years. Her husband is a farmer, but he hopes to create another business by driving a motorcyle taxi when he is free. Through this new business he will be able to generate additional income to support his family. Bunthy is applying for her first loan of $500 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike taxi for her husband

loans.name: Tsagaandorj

texts.en: A. Tsagaandorj is 44 years old and lives with her four children in Uvs province in western Mongolia. Her oldest daughter attends University and her youngest daughter and two sons currently attend a local secondary school. Tsagaandorj operates a grocery retail trading business in her town. She sells a variety of food-stuffs at a stand at the local market. Tsagaandorj started her grocery business in 1998 with 200,000 tugrugs (about $140 USD). She has slowly found success and recently used the profits from her business to remodel her home and build a new garage. Although it was a struggle at times in the beginning, her business has achieved a level of stable operations. For the future, Tsagaandorj hopes to continue to expand her business and save money, as two of her children will start university in the next few years. She says, "I want to be able provide for all of my children's university tuition costs". She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (about $1050 USD) loan to purchase more supplies and food items for her store.

loans.use: to purchase more supplies and food items for her store.

loans.name: Theresah

texts.en: Theresah A. has a beauty salon and also sells wigs; weave on, mesh and do on at castle near yamoransah.  Theresah has received junior high education.  She is married and has five dependants. Her husband is a fitter. Theresah has been selling wigs; weave on mesh ECT since 1995. She supports the husband in the settlement of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more hair products to sell and also use on her costumers hair. She wishes to plough back the new profit form her expanded business.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more hair products to sell and also use on her costumers hair.

loans.name: Malamine

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Malamine D. a 27 ans, célibataire, il réside dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Hamdallaye Extension, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur D. après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès notamment la vente de carburants, s’est initié au domaine du commerce plus précisément la vente des articles divers d’Alimentation (Eau minérale, boisson,  savon, thé Lipton, et cartes de recharge de téléphone Malitel/Orange, etc.) dans une boutique située à Wayerma I Sikasso. Il mène cette activité il y a environ trois  ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter, auprès de commerçants grossistes sur place et des représentants des deux réseaux de télécommunication : 10 paquets de boissons NBB, 30 cartons d’Eaux minérales, 2 cartons de lipton, 5 cartons de savons et de cartes de recharge Malitel/Orange, etc. Il vend ses marchandises en gros et en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des toutes couches sociales de la ville.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Malamine D. is 27 years old and single. He lives in a large traditional extended family in Hamdallaye Extension, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (Third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After running several activities unsuccessfully, in particular, the sale of fuel, Mr. D. learned the field of retail business. More precisely, he now sells various food items (Mineral water, beverages, soap, Lipton tea and mobile phone cards recharge Malite / Orange etc...) in a shop located in Wayerma I Sikasso. He has been in this business for about three years. He is very much in demand by his customers for the quality of his products.

To meet the demand of his ever increasing customers, he decided to join the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, this is his first individual loan with them.

With this loan, he hopes to buy from local wholesale merchants and from representatives of the two telecommunications networks:

10 packs of beverages NBB, 30 boxes of mineral water, 2 boxes of Lipton, 5 boxes of soap, and mobile phone recharge cards Malite / Orange etc...

He sells his items wholesale or retail to customers generally from the town' s various social strata.

With this loan, he plans on making a monthly profit of 250 000 FCFA, which he will use mainly to increase his business, contribute to the family's expenses, pay back his loan and invest the rest in his activity.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various food items.

loans.name: Benade

texts.en:
Benade S. is currently in the business of selling food in a restaurant, and is requesting a loan to buy soft drinks, such as sodas, water and juice to sell.  Benade is 28 years old and is married to a car driver. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy soft drinks such as sodas, water and juice to sell

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly S. is 39 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a professional weaver who is able to make about US$2 of profit every day, while her husband is a construction worker who builds houses. He typically makes US$3 a day. This couple has six children and all of them are in school. Ly S. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase silk clothes to sell at the local market.

loans.use: To purchase silk clothes to sell

loans.name: Yanet

texts.es:
Yanet tiene 25 años, vive con su pareja (Eduardo) de 24 años, que estudia medicina veterinaria. Ellos tienen un hijo de 6 años, que es el motivo por el cual se esfuerzan a diario y a pesar de ser jóvenes quieren salir adelante para asegurar la educación de su hijo.

Ella es técnica en enfermería y trabaja en un Centro de Salud cercano a la zona donde vive, ahí atiende desde muy temprano a los múltiples pacientes que acuden diariamente al centro en busca de ayuda médica. 
A parte de esta encomiable labor, también ayuda en la chacra a su esposo donde cultivan frutas cítricas desde hace 5 años, además él está trabajando en una veterinaria.
El trabajo en el campo es cansado, pero ellos casi no descansan con tal de asegurar su futuro y llegar a tener una chacra más grande; es así como el trabajo del cultivo sumado, a las ganancias que tienen con sus otros trabajos pueden vivir cómodamente, y a pesar de ser una pareja muy joven siempre piensan en progresar para vivir mejor en el futuro.

Este es el segundo préstamo de Yanet con MFP y promete ser cumplida y responsable son sus pagos, como lo es en su vida diaria. A su vez, está muy satisfecha con el trabajo de su banco comunal porque está conformado por personas responsables. El dinero que ahora solicita lo invertirá en la compra de abono y fertilizantes para sus tierras de cultivo, porque quieren asegurar las próximas cosechas.
texts.en:
Yanet is 25 years old lives and with her partner, Eduardo, who is 24 years old and studying veterinary medicine. They have a 6 year old son, who is their motivation for their work every day. Even though they are young, they want to get ahead in life to provide for their son's education.

She is a nurse technician and works at a health center close to where she lives. Starting early in the day she tends to the many patients who come to the center each day looking for medical assistance. In addition to this praiseworthy job, she also helps in her husband's fields where they have grown citrus fruit for 5 years. He also works at a veterinary clinic.

The work in the fields is tiring, but they almost never rest so that they can provide for the future and come to have a bigger plot of land. They are able to live comfortably from the combination of their work in the fields and their income from their other jobs, and despite being a very young couple they are always thinking of progressing and living better in the future.

This is the second loan Yanet has had with MFP and she promises to repay it and be responsible with her payments, just as she is every day of her life. She is very satisfied with the work of her community bank because it is made up of responsible people. The money she is asking for now will be invested to buy fertilizers for their farmlands, because they want to feel secure of the coming harvest.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
El señor Juan R. está muy agradecido por su cooperación en el anterior crédito. 
Nuevamente está solicitando un préstamo para poder pagarles a sus proveedores y así poder surtir de más materia prima. 
Planea pagar el crédito con una parte de las ganancias del negocio ya que es la fuente de ingresos de su familia.
texts.en:
Juna R. is so pleased with the past loan he had received. Currently he is seeking to have a loan to be able to pay his suppliers, allowing him to have access to more materials. He plans on taking some of the income he has earned from his business to pay the loan. His business is the only source of income for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay his suppliers.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 27-year-old single man living with his parents and three brothers. He has owned a car repair shop since 2008 where he provides services to his village and the neighboring villages. In addition, he sells engine oil in his shop.

Today, Ali is requesting $1,200 to buy more engine oil and needed repair tools.

loans.use: To buy more engine oil and needed repair tools

loans.name: United Kerosene Dealers Group

texts.en: Moses F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Kerosene Dealers. He is 35 years old and is married with two children, 4 and 8 years old. He also cares for a sibling. Moses and his family live in the Red Light community and he sells in the Red Light market, the largest market in Liberia, which is located in Paynesville near Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. Moses is a freshman university student studying business. His business is the sale of kerosene which he buys by the barrel and sells per gallon in the Red Light market from a table. He has been running this business for five years and hopes to own a petroleum station in the near future. Moses sells a good product in order to attract more customers to buy from him but sometime faces difficulty in getting kerosene from importers due to shortages in the market. Moses needs this loan to purchase additional kerosene to sell. He dreams of being successful enough to improve his family's living conditions. In the photo, Moses is the one holding the sign. Ayerics K. is inset at lower right. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today!

loans.use: To purchase additional kerosene to sell

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.es:
Ricardo R. T., es casado, tiene 32 años de edad y tres hijos. Los dos mayores van a la escuela, el mas pequeño tiene dos años de edad.
Su esposa le ayuda con la venta de suéteres, su negocio es una fábrica de suéteres y al mismo tiempo, compra y vende suéteres. Don Ricardo vende su mercadería en el mercado de Tecpán a diferentes clientes los días de mercado.
El préstamo lo solicita para comprar materia prima y una máquina de cocer. Su sueño es incrementar sus ventas y tener un negocio más grande para mejorar su vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Ricardo R. T. is 32 years old, married, and has three children. His two older children attend school while his youngest child is only two years old.

His wife helps to sell sweaters that he manufactures, but he also buys sweaters to sell. Don Ricardo sells his merchandise at the market in Tecpán to different customers on the days the market is open. This loan will be used to buy raw materials and a sewing machine. His dream is to increase his sales and enlarge his business so that he can improve life for himself and his family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase equipment and materials

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia B. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 35 years old. Amalia is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Amalia owns a business that provides cargo transport services to local community members. Amalia has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Amalia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amalia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide her service. Amalia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Amalia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Titi

texts.en: Titi sells colorful sarongs at retail prices to make a living. Sarongs in Nigeria are worn at all occasions and are mostly worn by women and young ladies. She hopes to be a major distributor of sarongs in the future. She hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is 43 years old and married with three children. Her husband sells medicines to support their home. Titilayo is determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She duly says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: David Muiruri

texts.en:
David is a gentleman who is 31 years old. He is in the transport business where he uses a motorcycle to ferry people and goods from one place to another. He has been in this business for the past two years. He is married to Mary who is a farmer and they have one son aged 10 years and one daughter aged 6 years.

David was introduced to KADET by another existing KADET client. With the loan he has applied for, he plans to purchase another motorcycle for transport. He intends to invest back in KADET and buy a three-wheeler taxi (Tuk Tuk) with the extra profit generated from his business.

David’s future hopes are to own a fleet of transport vehicles and also employ more people. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman, very jovial and happy to serve his customers.

loans.use: To purchase another motorcycle

loans.name: Gloria De Jesus

texts.es:
la sra. Gloria de Jesus C. se dedica a la venta de granos de cafe y tambien vende golosinas de platanos fritas, tiene mas de 10 años de ejercer este tipo de actividad comercial lo que le permite agenciar ganancias que contribuyen a mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
el cafe que se produce en esta zona es de buen sabor y aroma ya que esta zona es una de las principales zonas productoras de café de Honduras, doña Gloria es una mujer que como muchas contribuyen con los gastos del hogar a su esposo.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar cafe y platanos.
texts.en:
Sra. Gloria de Jesus C. sells coffee beans and candied banana slices. She has been doing this work for more than ten years, and the income from it has allowed her to improve her standard of living and that of her family. The coffee that is grown in this area has a good flavour and aroma since this is one of the principal coffee-growing areas of Honduras. Gloria is one of the many women who help their husbands with household expenses. The loan will be used to buy coffee and bananas.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy coffee and bananas

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a married man who has five children. He started operating his retail shop eight months ago and has two employees. He also does farming to earn extra income. He is a member of Galaxy group in Faulu Kenya, where he saves KES 100 on a weekly basis. He uses his savings to boost his business. He has requested a loan of KES 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy maize flour and sugar. For him to take this loan, he has been guaranteed by the group members. He hopes to open up a supermarket in the future. He dreams of opening other business outlets.

loans.use: To buy sugar and maize flour

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en: Remedios M. is from the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 58 years old. Remedios is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Remedios operates a business venture in the services sector. The main source of income for the business comes from providing vehicle-repair services to local community members. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2007, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Remedios from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Lucas

texts.en: Lucas is 28 years old, married to a business lady and they are blessed with two children. For eleven years, he has been repairing bicycles and motorbikes. He was previously selling cereals to earn a living. He uses part of his income to pay wages to his two employees. He is a member of "Winners Kitengela" group in Faulu, Kenya, whose members guarantee each others' loans. Through the group, Lucas has requested a loan of Kes. 20, 000 to buy spare parts. He hopes to move into better business premises where he can get more customers. In ten years, he wants to open up another business and buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Lidia Candelaria

texts.es: Lidia es de 29 años de edad, es casada, tiene un hijo y una hija, se dedica a la actividad de comercio venta de ropa en general, en la actividad tiene aproximadamente 8 años de experiencia, en ASDIR solicita su segundo préstamo para incrementar su capital y poder surtir mejor su venta, el crédito anterior lo pago sin problema de atraso.
texts.en:
Lidia is 29 years old. She is married with one son and one daughter. She has been selling clothes of all sorts for around 8 years. She is requesting her second loan from ASDIR, to increase her working capital and enable her to carry a larger stock. She paid off the previous loan without falling behind on payments.

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Angelle

texts.en:
Angelle C. lives in the village of Greenheights, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 23 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she sells ocean-caught fish to people who live in her community. She has been in this business for more than three years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Angelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI and is applying for a new loan for 8,000 PHP to buy additional fish to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell to her customers

location.town: Green Heights, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis O

loans.name: Luz Mercedes

texts.es:
La Señora. Luz Mercedes Calderón es socia del banco comunal Sociedad 12 de Abril, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, ciudad que es reconocida por su belleza arquitectónica de su centro histórico, fue nombrada como Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad el 1 de diciembre de 1999, su gastronomía, su gente y su cultura hacen de esta una ciudad hermosa y calida.

La Señora. Luz Mercedes tiene 35 años,  es casada y tiene 3 hijos de 15, 13 y 9 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos estudian en el colegio y su último hijo en la escuela, su esposo trabaja como estibador, no tienen casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.

Nuestras socia es comerciante de verduras y frutas, realiza esta actividad hace 15 años, tiene un puesto propio en el mercado 12 de Abril, y labora de domingo a domingo sin descansar un solo día desde las 7 a.m. hasta las 5 p.m.

Se encentra en su quinto ciclo, los créditos anteriores los a invertido en su negocio, su nuevo préstamo es para comprar más frutas y verduras y así ampliar su negocio.

Su meta es llegar a tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Luz Mercedes Calderón is a member of the communal bank, Sociedad 12 de Abril. She lives in the city of Cuenca, a city recognized for its architectural beauty and its historic center. It was named an UNESCO World Heritage Site on December 1, 1999. Its cuisine, its people, and its culture make this a lovely and warm city. Luz Mercedes is 35 years old, married, and has three children aged 15, 13 and 9. Her oldest two children are in high school and her youngest is in elementary school. Her husband works as a longshoreman (dockhand). They don't own their own house, so they are renting one. She works as a fruit and vegetable merchant, which she has done for 15 years. She has her own stand in El Mercado 12 de Abril (The 12th of April Market). She works from Sunday to Sunday (7 days a week) without taking a day off from 7 AM to 5 PM. She is in her 5th loan cycle. She has invested the previous loans in her business. Her new loan will be used to buy more fruits and vegetables and to expand her business. Her goal is to eventually own her own home.

Translated from Spanish by David Cannon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy carrots, potatoes, yuca, sprouts, bananas, apples, mangos, etc.

loans.name: Kikozza Women's Development Group - Mityana

texts.en:
On the strength of her hard work-driven approach and her courage of conviction, 35-year-old Jane N. has obtained a strong business niche for her beauty salon business in Kiryokya-Mityana.  By and large she has used her strength of character to forestall and overcome the inevitable challenges that come with operating her nine-year-old business. That has been her reliable winning calling card.

Jane also ekes out side profits from a retail business enterprise. In a given week, Jane says she makes profits that amount to about 35,000 Ugandan shillings. With her share of this loan to the  Kikozza Women's Development Group, whose members are pictured in the photo that accompanies this profile, Jane envisages being in a better position to buy more cosmetics and other salon equipment like hair weaving implements for her salon.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and hair weaving implements for a beauty salon.

loans.name: Khat

texts.en:
Mrs. Khat N. is a 31-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Tom Province. Khat N. is married to Mr. Ngim, age 30, who works with her in the farming business. This couple is blessed to two young children, both of whom are attending school. 

As the raiN. season approaches, Khat N. doesn’t have supplies to use on her farm, so she  is asking for a loan in order to buy fertilizer and crop seed for growing. (Mrs. Khat N.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and crop seed

loans.name: Lorena Monica

texts.es:
Mónica de 30 años, vive en una zona periurbana en Paraíso de Guayaquil lugar caracterizado por su montañas y caminos de tierra. Ella vende almuerzos todos los días para poder mantener a su familia.    

Comenzó con el negocio de almuerzos para poder ayudar con los gastos familiares, vende comidas típicas en los almuerzos como caldo de bola, caldo de pata, arroz con pollo etc. Tiene un promedio de 60 clientes al día que le compran los almuerzos. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar una cocina industrial para hacer mas platos ya que ahora solo esta cocinando en su cocina pequeña. En el futuro quiere tener su propio restaurante y ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
Mónica, 30, lives in a periurban area of Paraíso in Guayaquil, a place notable for its hills and unpaved streets. She sells lunches daily to support her family. She started the lunch business to help with family expenses. She sells typical dishes at lunch like: caldo de bola (stuffed plantain balls soup), caldo de pata (beef hoof soup), chicken and rice, etc. She serves 60 customers daily on average. She wants to use the loan to buy an industrial stove so that she can make more meals since she is currently cooking on a small stove. In the future she’d like to have her own restaurant and expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For an industrial stove.

loans.name: Jose

texts.es:
José de 63 años, es taxista tiene dos hijos y viven en una zona urbana llamada “Suburbio” caracterizada porque la mayoría de habitantes son comerciantes informales. 

Cuando se jubilo tubo que comprar un taxi para poder solventar los gastos de su familia. Su trabajo lo realiza recorriendo todas las calles de Guayaquil, trabaja en horarios fáciles desde las 07h00am hasta las 18h00am para poder dedicarle tiempo a su familia. El quiere seguir trabajando para así solventar económicamente a su familia.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar materiales de construcción como cemento, bloques y pinturas para hacer un departamento en su casa para alquilarlo y así cuando se enferme tener dinero adicional. En el futuro quiere mejorar su casa.
texts.en:
José, 63, is a taxi driver. He has two children and they live in an urban zone called “Suburbio” which is notable because most of its residents are informal merchants. When he retired he had to buy a taxi in order to meet family expenses. His job consists in traveling throughout all of Guayaquil’s streets. He works easy schedules from 7am until 6pm so that he can spend time with his family. He wants to continue working in order to meet his family’s economic needs. He wants to use the loan to buy building materials and supplies like cement, concrete blocks and paint to build an apartment in his house to rent out so that he can have additional income if he were to become ill. In the future he’d like to make home improvements.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For cement, paint and concrete blocks.

loans.name: Leonie

texts.en:
Leonie V. is from the village of Estrada. She is 37 years old. Leonie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Leonie owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Leonie has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leonie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Leonie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leonie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Abu Bakarr

texts.en:
This is 37-year-old Abu Bakarr.  He is married, and has two children aged 8 and 1. He has two additional dependents, who live with him because they came in as family assistance and for their schooling. 

 In 1999, Abu Bakarr established his used clothing business. He began his business because he wanted to develop self-reliance. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about 910,000SLL every month from this business. He needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL. He requires a loan in order to buy bales of used clothing. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 182,000SLL. 

In the future, Abu Bakarr plans to complete his house, to expand his business, and to educate his children to university level so that they can take care of him when he is old. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy bales of used clothes

loans.name: Indiana Maria

texts.es: Indiana tiene 44 años, es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad que están a su cargo. Desde hace mas de 6 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que sus inicios son con esfuerzos propios, pues desde muy joven su Mama le enseño a ganarse la vida vendiendo ropa y cosméticos, Indiana no tuvo la oportunidad de finalizar sus estudios, por lo que tenía que ayudar a su Mama a vender es por eso que lucha todos los días para darle esa oportunidad a sus hijos, a pesar de las difíciles situaciones que ha enfrentado sigue con esta actividad. Ella invertirá el financiamiento en materia prima. Sueña con mejorar su vivienda, pues todavía no tiene ciertos servicios básicos.
texts.en:
Indiana is 44 years old, and she has two minor children under her care.  She has been working in her business for over six years.  She started the business through her own efforts.  When she was very young, her mother taught her how to earn a living by selling clothes and cosmetics.

Indiana did not have the opportunity to complete her education.  She had to help her mother sell.  That is why she struggles every day to give this opportunity to her children.

In spite of the difficult situations she has faced, she continues with her business activity.

She will use the loan for merchandise.  She dreams of improving her home because she still does not have certain basic services.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Yeremiah

texts.en: Yeremiah is a 54-year-old married man with three children, living in his own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His goal is to set up income-generating activities for each of his children. He trades in goats and has been in the business for two years, reaping great profits. His major challenges are the markets are far (apart), and he has limited capital to meet the demands of his customers. Yeremiah would like to set up a ranch in the future. He needs the loan to purchase goats to sell.

loans.use: Purchasing goats for sale

loans.name: Amigas De Corazón Group

texts.es:
La Banca Comunal “AMIGAS DE CORAZÓN” iniciará su  primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, en el Centro Focal de Senkata.  Está compuesta por ocho integrantes.  La mesa directiva está compuesta por la presidenta la señora Rosa, tesorera la señora Ana y secretaria de actas la señora Leonor. Los negocios que ellas desempeñan son variados de comercio, servicio y también producción.
En el caso de la presidenta, señora  Rosa tiene un hogar conformado por su esposo y 2 hijos.  El negocio de la señora Rosa ha sido y es el de venta de comida, en el tiempo ha cambiando de plato, primero vendía tostado de haba y chicharron de llama,  actualmente vende chicharrón de pollo.   También tiene proyectado impulsar con el crédito de este ciclo el negocio de empastado de cuadernos.  Le colabora en su trabajo sus hija de 23 años.
Cuando se le consulta sobre lo que le gusta de Pro Mujer ella indica que le gusta el consultorio.
Es importante hacer notar que varias socias asumen la estrategia de tener dos negocios, para contar con ingresos de manera contínua, si un negocio decae, el otro la sostiene.
texts.en:
The 'Amigas de Corazón' community bank is starting its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer, in the Senkata regional office.  The bank has eight members.  Its board is made up of the president, Rosa, the treasurer, Ana, and the secretary, Leonor.  The businesses that the women have are varied and include commerce, services and also production.

The bank's president, Rosa, lives with her husband and 2 children.  Her business is selling meals.  Over time she has changed the dishes she sells.  She used to sell toasted beans and crispy fried llama meat.  She currently sells crispy fried chicken.  Rosa plans to use this loan to drive her book binding business in which she is helped by her 23 year-old daughter.

When we asked Rosa what she liked about Pro Mujer, she replied that she likes the doctor's office.

It is important to note here that several group members have a two business strategy so that they can make money continuously; if one business doesn't do well, the other one supports it.

loans.use: To buy chicken and sheets of paper

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika sells bed sheets at Beregovo market. She is married with two children. Monika has been in her business for five years. Her monthly income is about 5,500 hryvnia (UAH), and her working capital is 15,000 UAH. She likes her business because it does not change with the seasons. People are always purchasing bed sheets, most often as a gift. Monika would like to increase her assortment to attract more clients. She is requesting a loan of 6,500 UAH. Monika would like to develop her business further so that she can increase her income and take better care of her family.

loans.use: To increase her assortment

loans.name: Norma
